results.title: Jamaica
results.brief_description: Jamaica is the largest and most lovely island in the British West Indies. A brief glimpse of the market at Kingston, sugar cane plantations, rivers and waterfalls which make the island a Caribbean paradise. Also shows fishing and rafting.
results.description: Jamaica is the largest and most lovely island in the British West Indies. A brief glimpse of the market at Kingston, sugar cane plantations, rivers and waterfalls which make the island a Caribbean paradise. Also shows fishing and rafting.

results.title: Jalan jalan: a journey in Sudanese Java
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Tom Daly and Michael Rubbo
results.brief_description: This is a film without commentary but with all the sights and sounds, colour and tempo of life of the exotic Indonesian islands in the Java Sea. Here Jalan, Jalan can mean either going on a journey or simply taking a stroll. It is a film full of surprises in the bustling half-modern, half-ancient city of Jakarta, capital of the island republic, and in the lovely countryside. (An abridged and revised version of ‘Wet Earth and Warm People’ made for younger audiences.)

results.title: Jakob Gimpel, pianist: program No. 17
results.creator_credit: Official Films, Paul Gordon and George Moskov
results.brief_description: A Frederic Chopin recital performed by Polish-American pianist, Jakob Gimpel, featuring “Etude in E Major” (Opus 10, No. 3), “Waltz in C Sharp Minor” (Opus 64, No. 2) and “Mazurka in B Flat Major” (Opus 7, No. 1). Arranged by Roy Douglas into the ballet “Le Sylphide”.

results.title: Jake: today I became a man
results.brief_description: Jake is an extraordinary child who just so happens to love dressing up and performing. His resolution to be himself and carve out an identity for himself regardless of societal expectations is inspiring. A remarkable story told in Jake’s language in which he articulately discusses growing up and his love of singing and performing in drag. An eye opening piece which challenges assumptions of personal identity and that kids do understand themselves and their ‘place’ in the world.
